poem:
### Cairo Talks

In the Cairo room,
voices shuffle like papers,
ceasefire folded into corners.
Kamala's words, 
a prayer strung between columns,
sewn into the morning's screen glow.
Here, in the thin breath
of negotiation, hope balances
on the edge of an if,
a delicate hostage
to what could be.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Israel-Gaza war live: Israeli negotiators in Cairo for ceasefire and hostage talks as Kamala Harris urges peace 1.05pm BST Today so far US vice-president and Democratic presidential candidate Kamala Harris said in her Democratic national convention speech on Thursday that now was the time for a ceasefire and hostage release deal in Israel’s war in Gaza. “I will always stand up for Israel’s right to defend itself,” Harris said while adding “what has happened in". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
